awd_titl_txt: DMREF: Collaborative Research: Establishing the platform of quasi-one-dimensional topological insulators with emergent functionalities.
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Description: Applying the concept of topology to solid state systems has revolutionized our understanding of quantum phenomena and materials, and inspired the design of new functionalities in electronic, atomic, photonic, mechanical, and acoustic systems. For instance, topological insulators (TIs) are a class of materials that are electrically insulating in the bulk, but host conductive surface states. Protected by symmetry and topology, these surface states are immune to impurities and thus enable making near-perfect devices from imperfect interfaces, which are important for both conventional and quantum information technology. However, there exist a number of critical challenges in current TI materials that must be addressed before realizing their full potential. This project aims at overcoming these challenges by focusing on a new class of materials, quasi-one-dimensional (quasi-1D) TIs with emergent functionalities. An iterative loop of theoretical modeling and prediction, material synthesis, and characterization will be established to discover different families of quasi-1D TIs and explore their unique properties for topological phenomena and functionalities. The project's success will shed light on the realization of topological quantum computing and low-power spintronics for next-generation information technology and sustainable energy solutions. Major educational activities will be integrated into the research activities by performing public outreach, training graduate and undergraduate students, increasing participation of under-represented groups, providing a new face to physics and materials science with two women in leadership positions on this team, and offering open access to research and education outputs to the technical community and general public.

Technical Description: To date, most of the identified TIs are either strongly bonded bulk materials or layered van der Waals materials. Despite their richness, fundamental obstacles and limitations exist in exhibiting the decisive properties and realizing the full promise of TIs, such as the restriction of surface Dirac cones to a specific cleavage plane, weak electronic interactions and limited tunability. Remarkably, a quasi-1D structure promises to overcome these challenges. The goals of this project include design and optimization of quasi-1D TI candidates, synthesis and characterization, tuning topological phase transitions by strain and temperature, and seeking 2D TIs in atomically thin layers of quasi-1D materials. Through complementary expertise and concerted efforts on theory and computation, material synthesis, spin- and angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy, nanofabrication, quantum transport, and neutron and x-ray scattering, the project is expected to lead to the discovery of novel TIs, phases and phenomena, controlling topological transitions, and enabling superior functionalities and fostering quantum technologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Topological insulators (TI) are insulating in the bulk yet conducting on the boundary, protected by symmetry and immune to perturbation. Besides revolutionizing our view of the quantum world, TIs equip us with the ability to create possible breakthrough technologies. This DMREF project aimed to establish the platform of quasi-one-dimensional (Q1D) TIs with emergent properties inaccessible to TIs of other forms. Our team achieved significant accomplishments through multiple iterative feedback loops linking theory, computation, synthesis, characterization, device fabrication, and external collaboration efforts.

DMREF teamwork

Our team established a rich Q1D platform for novel device engineering in the topological age. Based on Zhang’s prediction, Lv synthesized high-quality Bi4I4 single crystals with large side surfaces necessary for the ARPES measurements performed by Yi and Birgeneau. Combining the ARPES data, X-ray diffraction, Lau’s transport studies, and Zhang’s theory, we unambiguously identified a topological phase transition near 300 K in bulk Bi4I4. We demonstrated that the high-temperature phase is the first-ever weak TI, and that the low-temperature phase and Bi4Br4 are the only higher-order TIs to date that are semiconducting. Lau fabricated exfoliated Bi4I­4 field-effect transistors and Josephson transistors and demonstrated their gate tunability for the first time. 

External collaboration

Collaborating with the Min group at Seoul National University, Zhang theoretically showed that the atomic layers of Bi4I4 and Bi4Br4 could exhibit room-temperature quantum spin Hall (QSH) effect. In a scanning tunneling microscopy study guided by Zhang’s theory, the Hasan group at Princeton provided compelling evidence for such QSH step-edge states that persisted to 300 K.

Materials enrichment 

Furthermore, Lv and Zhang have established a complete structural and topological phase diagram for the Bi4I4-xBrx (0 ≤ x ≤4) family, with new structures and band topologies identified. In particular, the x = 2.8 case represents an ideal weak TI, as shown by Yi and Birgeneau’s ARPES experiment and Zhang’s first-principles calculation. In addition, Lv successfully synthesized a dozen of other high-quality Q1D materials and carried out exploratory syntheses with new Q1D materials and structures identified.

Other significant works

Additionally, our team made several other significant contributions to the field of quantum materials. Lau and Zhang critically reviewed fabrication challenges and emergent physics of moiré materials and demonstrated a quantum geometric mechanism for understanding and designing flat-band superconductors. Yi, Birgeneau and Zhang identified new correlated phases driven by van Hove singularities in Kagome metals and bilayer graphene. Zhang co-invented intelligent optical sensing enabled by quantum geometry (patented) and co-proposed geometric deep optical sensing. Birgeneau discovered new 2D magnetic materials with high Curie temperatures and topological excitations.

Public engagement

We established a website to document all our research data on the Q1D materials and made them findable, accessible, interoperable, and reusable to the public. We opened a twitter account to publicize relevant research results, NSF news, etc. In 2023 we organized a workshop, Q1D Topological Quantum Materials, documented in our free Youtube channel. In 2022 we introduced the MGI and DMREF programs, our key results in this project, the NASEM’s report – Protecting US Technological Advantage, and the CHIPS and Science Act across the UTD campus. Our PIs gave more than 120 invited talks at various institutes and conferences, and results in this project were disseminated in more than half of them. Our students and postdocs gave 30 talks in APS March Meetings to present results in this project.

National policy

Birgeneau led the DOE committee on justifying a high-performance reactor-based research facility and outlining a 50-year strategy for nuclear research. Birgeneau also contributed to the NASEM committee examining the intersection of national security, economic competitiveness, and research openness in the U.S. Their report, Protecting U.S. Technological Advantage, is poised to shape U.S. research policy significantly.

Student/postdoc training

Our team collectively provided comprehensive training for 3 K12 students, 5 REU students, 18 undergraduate students, 29 graduate students, and 9 postdocs. Some individuals underwent additional training to use national research facilities. Among these 64 trainees, 9 obtained Ph.D. degrees, 11 entered graduate school STEM programs, and 3 have become professors. Notably, two Ph.D. recipients were honored with the Steven Weinberg Research Awards from the Texas Section of APS in 2021 and 2023, one REU student was awarded an NSF Graduate Research Fellowship, and one UTD student received an Air Force Research Lab Summer Internship.

Broad participation

Our team has been active in increasing the participation of under-represented groups in STEM education and research. Birgeneau created a new endowed program and a new endowed fund for under-represented students at UC Berkeley. Birgeneau, Lau, and Yi are serving in various Diversity/Equity/Inclusion committees. Zhang and Lau supervised an LGBT (Ph.D. 2022) and a female (Ph.D. 2023), respectively, with their dissertations including studies of Q1D topological materials. Lv and Zhang mentored 3 female undergraduate students and a high school girl, respectively.
